harmonicFunction: The main progression uses a chromatic descending power chord sequence that creates strong forward momentum
The ♭VII (D5) and ♭VI (C5) chords are borrowed from E natural minor, giving the song its aggressive edge
The verse uses a more traditional I-♭VII-IV-I progression that provides stability
The bridge employs a classic IV-V-I cadence that builds tension before returning to the main theme
Power chords throughout maintain the heavy, anthemic character typical of 80s metal

techniques.name: Descending Power Chord Progressions
techniques.description: Classic chromatic descending power chord pattern that creates tension and release

notes: Creates dramatic effect through chromatic descent
Requires clean chord transitions between positions
Foundation of the song's memorable hook
sequence: Master individual power chord shapes (E5, D#5, C#5, B5)
Build up speed while maintaining clarity
tips: Keep consistent finger pressure across all chords
Use economy of motion between chord changes
Practice with a metronome to maintain timing

techniques.name: Heavy Palm Muting
techniques.description: Aggressive palm muting technique for chunky, percussive rhythm sections

notes: Creates the tight, percussive sound essential to metal rhythm
Applied primarily during verse sections
Contrasts with open chorus sections for dynamics
sequence: Apply to simple power chord patterns
Work on switching between muted and open
tips: Rest palm edge lightly on strings near bridge
Maintain consistent pressure for even tone
Practice switching between muted and open quickly
details.progression: E5 - B5 - E5 - A5 (all palm muted)

techniques.name: Whammy Bar Effects
techniques.description: Tremolo arm techniques for expressive lead guitar and solo sections

notes: Adds expressive elements to lead guitar sections
Requires guitar with tremolo bridge system
Used for pitch bending and vibrato effects
tips: Use gentle pressure for subtle effects
Keep guitar in tune after whammy use
details.progression: E major pentatonic with whammy effects

sections.name: Intro/Main Riff
sections.description: The iconic descending chromatic power chord pattern that defines the song
notes: Play with authority and clean chord transitions
Emphasize the downbeat of each chord change
This riff repeats throughout as the main hook

sections.name: Verse
sections.description: Palm muted power chord pattern creating tight, percussive rhythm foundation
notes: Heavy palm muting throughout for chunky tone
Consistent eighth-note rhythm pattern
Keep chord changes tight and percussive

sections.name: Chorus
sections.description: Open power chord progression with the signature descending ending
sections.progression: E5 - B5 - E5 - A5 - E5 - B5 - descending pattern
notes: Open, ringing chords without palm muting
Build energy through the progression
End with the signature descending chromatic run

sections.name: Bridge
sections.description: Ascending power chord pattern that builds tension before the final chorus
notes: Ascending pattern creates building tension
Contrasts with the usual descending patterns
Sets up the return to the main chorus effectively

sections.name: Guitar Solo
sections.description: Pentatonic-based solo with whammy bar effects and expressive bending
notes: Focus on E major pentatonic scale patterns
Use whammy bar for expressive pitch bending
Simple but effective melodic phrasing

guitar.recommended: Gibson Les Paul or similar solid body with humbuckers
alternatives: Any solid body with humbucker pickups
guitar.pickup: Humbucker pickups for high-gain distortion tone

amp.recommended: Marshall JCM800 or high-gain tube amplifier

effects.distortion: High-gain tube amp distortion or overdrive pedal
effects.other: Whammy bar/tremolo bridge system for solo effects

beginner.title: Power Chord Foundation
steps: Master basic power chord shapes (E5, B5, A5)

intermediate.title: Technique Development
steps: Develop heavy palm muting for metal rhythm
Practice switching between muted and open sections

advanced.title: Expression and Lead Work
steps: Learn E major pentatonic scale for solos
Master whammy bar techniques and effects
Develop personal expression within the metal framework
Perfect timing and dynamics throughout the song

acdc.title: Thunderstruck
acdc.similarity: Similar high-energy metal approach with signature riffs

acdc.title: Back in Black
acdc.similarity: Power chord foundation and palm muting techniques

similarTechniques.title: Crazy Train
similarTechniques.similarity: Famous for its descending chromatic riff pattern

similarTechniques.title: Master of Puppets
similarTechniques.similarity: Demonstrates advanced palm muting in metal rhythm

commonMistakes: Rushing the descending chord progression - take time for clean transitions
Inconsistent palm muting pressure causing uneven tone
Over-using the whammy bar - subtle effects are more musical
Not contrasting verse and chorus dynamics properly
practiceRoutine: Start with slow practice of the descending progression
Work on palm muting with simple patterns before full song
Practice verse and chorus sections separately before combining
Use metronome to maintain consistent timing throughout
Focus on clean chord transitions at slower tempos first
metronomeWork: Practice at 100 BPM initially, work up to full 140 BPM
Focus on downbeat emphasis in the descending progression
Practice palm muted sections with steady eighth-note feel
Work on timing consistency between different song sections
